summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Office of Internal Affairs referral to the DOJ OIG concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York on August 10, 2019. It details allegations that two correctional staff failed to conduct required inmate checks (3 a.m. and 5 a.m. rounds) prior to Epstein being found unresponsive, leading to charges of inattention to duty, failure to follow policy, and endangering inmate safety.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, and was later pronounced dead. He is the central subject of the incident report.

persons.name: Officer
persons.context: A correctional officer (GL-05) who, along with a Materials Handler Supervisor, allegedly failed to conduct the 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. inmate counts. The officer stated 'we messed up' and appeared distraught.

persons.name: Materials Handler Supervisor
persons.context: A staff member (WS-04) who, along with a correctional officer, allegedly failed to conduct the required inmate counts. This person is a subject of the internal affairs investigation.

persons.name: Operations Lieutenant
persons.context: The lieutenant who responded to the medical emergency, administered CPR, and took statements from the involved officers regarding their failure to conduct rounds.

persons.name: Union President
persons.context: The local union president whom the involved staff members wanted to contact to review any memorandums they would have to write about the incident.

connections.description: Both were on duty and jointly responsible for conducting inmate counts. They both admitted to failing to perform the 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. rounds.
The officer had custodial and supervisory responsibility for inmate Epstein's safety and was required to conduct checks on his cell.
The supervisor shared responsibility for the inmate's safety and was required to conduct checks on his cell.
The officer reported the failure to conduct rounds to the Operations Lieutenant during the incident response.
The officer sought to have the Union President review any written statements about the incident.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found unresponsive in cell
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his assigned cell (Z06-220) in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. CPR was administered, and he was transported to a hospital.

events.title: Failure to conduct inmate counts
events.description: Officers admitted to not conducting the mandatory 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. inmate counts/rounds on the Special Housing Unit where Epstein was held.

events.title: Epstein pronounced dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m. by an emergency room physician at Beekman Hospital.

events.title: Internal Affairs referral to OIG
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons Office of Internal Affairs formally referred the incident to the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General for investigation.

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
Special Housing Unit (SHU), Cell Z06-220, L-tier
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York at approximately 6:33 a.m. on August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

Two Bureau of Prisons staff members—a Correctional Officer and a Materials Handler Supervisor—admitted to failing to conduct the mandatory 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. inmate counts/rounds prior to the discovery.
The Operations Lieutenant's memorandum records one officer stating 'we messed up' and 'I messed up, she's not to blame we didn't do any rounds.'
The involved staff claimed they were traumatized by the event, requested to go home, and wanted their union president to review any statements they wrote.

The BOP Office of Internal Affairs referred the case to the DOJ Office of the Inspector General on August 12, 2019, citing allegations of endangering inmate safety, inattention to duty, and failure to follow policy.
